Hal Kemp began to play the piano
at the age of six. His theme song
"'I'll Miss You When Summer Is
Gone," was written by him while he
was a student at the University of
North Carolina. He is an expert tennis player. He dubbed his first band,
organized at high school, "The Merrymakers."
These enthralling facts—tossed in
purely for their cultural value—can
be gleaned from five minutes conversation with any genuine devotee of M.
Kemp's efforts.
But for the Johns Hopkins University, today- the most important fact
about Hal Kemp is that he will be on
the platform, at 10 p. in., come Monday eve, when the band strikes up for
the Second Cotillion at the Lord Baltimore Hotel And, for the Cotillion
Board the most important fact about
Hal Kemp—or anything else for that
matter--is that the Johns Hopkins
University seems prepared en masse
to pay $3.50 a head for privilege of
seeing him wave the baton.
The climax of the evening will come
with the grand march, led by Miss
Mary Shepherd, sponsor of the Cotillion, and David Erck, President. At
midnight, Brian Murphy will present Miss Shepherd with flowers.
In building towards that climax,
the Cotillion Board is engaged at
present in feverish activity designed
to turn the Lord Baltimore next
Monday night into a lane flowing with
milk and honey. Mr. Kemp, himself,
seems to be acting as Midas by proxy
so far as the Cotillion Board tickets
are concerned. The "pasteboards"—
as they are known to the trade-are moving with a celerity unprecedented in the 'recent history of Hopkins dances.

Dr.DuncanJohnson Capital Is Mecca
Dies Of Jaundice Of Student Union
Professor Of Botany Connected With Hopkins
For 44 Years
Dr. Duncan Starr Johnson, Professor of Botany and Director of the
Botanical Gardens and Botanical Laboratory died at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital. He was 69 years old and had
been connected with the University
for forty-four years.
While vacationing in Venezula during the Christmas holidays, Dr. Johnson was taken ill with jaundice. Soon
after his return to the University, he
was forced to enter the hospital. He
was operated on February 8. and
grew steadily worse until his death
Tuesday morning.
Born in Cromwell, Conn. in 1867,
Dr. Johnson received his B.S. degree
at Wesdeyan in 1892, and entered
the Johns Hopkins Graduate Department of Botany in 1893, and has been
closely connected with the University
ever since. He received his Ph.D. degree here in 1897, and the following
year he held a Bruce Fellowship. In
1898 he became assistant in Botany,
advancing to associate in 1899, associate professor in 1901, and in 1906
he became full professor. At about
this time the University acquired the
Homewood grounds, and Dr. Johnson
organized the Botanical Gar$1en, and
the greenhouse connected with the
garden. This greenhouse, was one of
tme first buildings to be completed
at the Homewood site, finished many
years before Gilman Hall.
Under his leadership the Botany
Department has been built up from
very small beginnings, and he himself
was recognized by his colleagues as
one of the most prominent leaders
and authorities in plant morphology
in America. He was regarded by
his colleagues as one of the finest and
most conscientious teachers in the
fi4eld. Throughout his life he has
maintained an active interest in all
fields of Botanical Science and in the
whole plant kingdom.
Dr. Johnson served as Secretary of
the Botanical Society of America
from 1907 until 1910, and in 1912 he
was vice-president of the American
Association for the Advancement of
Science for the Botanical Section and

Saturday's march to Washington
is under the sponsorship of The
American Youth Congress which has
a membership well over 2,000,000.
Proceedings are to be opened by a
parade to the White House, in which
college seniors dressed in caps and
gowns will participate.
Later, from the portico of the
White House, President Roosevelt
will address the assemblage, after
receiving a petition for passing the
American Youth. This written petition includes the signature of 1,000,000 American Youth. Sightseeing
tours, demonstrations, and entertainment will complete the day.

Kouwenhoven To Speak
Sunday Evening, February 28, Professor W. Kouwenhoven will address
the Washington Alumni Association,
at a supper meeting, to be held in the
Cosmos Club in Washington, D.C.
His subject will be "Electric Shock."

Flannels Freighted
Lest Freshie Freeze
Mother Sends Son His Winter UnderWear; Asks Secretary To See
That He Wears Them
"I've received a lot of unusual requests, but this one beats them all",
says Ben Sclunoker, executive secretary of the University of Minnesota's
Y. M. C. A.
A mother, worried about her freshman son, wrote him the following
letter:
"I am sending you three suits of
woolen underwear under *parate
cover. Please see to it that my boy
wears them as he should during this
cold weather."
Since it's the right time of the
school year to tell stories about
freshmen, Schrnoker relates this one:
"Not long ago a freshman stopped
me and said. 'Can you please tell me
in what building the campus is?'"

In Regard To Rights
A goodly percentage of students often think and react
very strongly to problems of interest to them. These men
condemn or approve inwardly with enthusiasm. They
resent certain statements or allegations; they defend
boldly certain measures or attitudes—but all mentally,
to themselves. Why do they not let the world share in
their opinions? Why not aid in pushing whatever viewpoint they hold to further realization? Why do not
they put their thought in writing?

fundamentally. But one thing we should all agree
upon; and that is that there should be no denial of the
right of any side to express his opinion. And to uphold
this right we pledge ourselves wholeheartedly.
Once we have arrived at a conclusion, we will adhere
to it firmly and persistently. We hope to stir up some
thought; we hope to find some disagreement. And we
can concretely find this out by the written reactions of
students in letters to the editor.
Any correspondence, except that of a slanderous,
Libelous, or anonymous nature, will be respected and
printed-4n columns parallel to our written opinions.
Any request to withold publishing of the correspondent's
name will be honored and positively adhered to. A timehonored and permanent journalistic principle, into which
we firmly believe, will oblige us to insure absolute
secrecy of a writer's identity, if it is so requested.

Hal Kemp began to play the piano
at the age of six. His theme song
"'I'll Miss You When Summer Is
Gone," was written by him while he
was a student at the University of
North Carolina. He is an expert tennis player. He dubbed his first band,
organized at high school, "The Merrymakers."
These enthralling facts—tossed in
purely for their cultural value—can
be gleaned from five minutes conversation with any genuine devotee of M.
Kemp's efforts.
But for the Johns Hopkins University, today- the most important fact
about Hal Kemp is that he will be on
the platform, at 10 p. in., come Monday eve, when the band strikes up for
the Second Cotillion at the Lord Baltimore Hotel And, for the Cotillion
Board the most important fact about
Hal Kemp—or anything else for that
matter--is that the Johns Hopkins
University seems prepared en masse
to pay $3.50 a head for privilege of
seeing him wave the baton.
The climax of the evening will come
with the grand march, led by Miss
Mary Shepherd, sponsor of the Cotillion, and David Erck, President. At
midnight, Brian Murphy will present Miss Shepherd with flowers.
In building towards that climax,
the Cotillion Board is engaged at
present in feverish activity designed
to turn the Lord Baltimore next
Monday night into a lane flowing with
milk and honey. Mr. Kemp, himself,
seems to be acting as Midas by proxy
so far as the Cotillion Board tickets
are concerned. The "pasteboards"—
as they are known to the trade-are moving with a celerity unprecedented in the 'recent history of Hopkins dances.

Dr.DuncanJohnson Capital Is Mecca
Dies Of Jaundice Of Student Union
Professor Of Botany Connected With Hopkins
For 44 Years
Dr. Duncan Starr Johnson, Professor of Botany and Director of the
Botanical Gardens and Botanical Laboratory died at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital. He was 69 years old and had
been connected with the University
for forty-four years.
While vacationing in Venezula during the Christmas holidays, Dr. Johnson was taken ill with jaundice. Soon
after his return to the University, he
was forced to enter the hospital. He
was operated on February 8. and
grew steadily worse until his death
Tuesday morning.
Born in Cromwell, Conn. in 1867,
Dr. Johnson received his B.S. degree
at Wesdeyan in 1892, and entered
the Johns Hopkins Graduate Department of Botany in 1893, and has been
closely connected with the University
ever since. He received his Ph.D. degree here in 1897, and the following
year he held a Bruce Fellowship. In
1898 he became assistant in Botany,
advancing to associate in 1899, associate professor in 1901, and in 1906
he became full professor. At about
this time the University acquired the
Homewood grounds, and Dr. Johnson
organized the Botanical Gar$1en, and
the greenhouse connected with the
garden. This greenhouse, was one of
tme first buildings to be completed
at the Homewood site, finished many
years before Gilman Hall.
Under his leadership the Botany
Department has been built up from
very small beginnings, and he himself
was recognized by his colleagues as
one of the most prominent leaders
and authorities in plant morphology
in America. He was regarded by
his colleagues as one of the finest and
most conscientious teachers in the
fi4eld. Throughout his life he has
maintained an active interest in all
fields of Botanical Science and in the
whole plant kingdom.
Dr. Johnson served as Secretary of
the Botanical Society of America
from 1907 until 1910, and in 1912 he
was vice-president of the American
Association for the Advancement of
Science for the Botanical Section and

Saturday's march to Washington
is under the sponsorship of The
American Youth Congress which has
a membership well over 2,000,000.
Proceedings are to be opened by a
parade to the White House, in which
college seniors dressed in caps and
gowns will participate.
Later, from the portico of the
White House, President Roosevelt
will address the assemblage, after
receiving a petition for passing the
American Youth. This written petition includes the signature of 1,000,000 American Youth. Sightseeing
tours, demonstrations, and entertainment will complete the day.

Kouwenhoven To Speak
Sunday Evening, February 28, Professor W. Kouwenhoven will address
the Washington Alumni Association,
at a supper meeting, to be held in the
Cosmos Club in Washington, D.C.
His subject will be "Electric Shock."

Lest Freshie Freeze
Mother Sends Son His Winter UnderWear; Asks Secretary To See
That He Wears Them
"I've received a lot of unusual requests, but this one beats them all",
says Ben Sclunoker, executive secretary of the University of Minnesota's
Y. M. C. A.
A mother, worried about her freshman son, wrote him the following
letter:
"I am sending you three suits of
woolen underwear under *parate
cover. Please see to it that my boy
wears them as he should during this
cold weather."
Since it's the right time of the
school year to tell stories about
freshmen, Schrnoker relates this one:
"Not long ago a freshman stopped
me and said. 'Can you please tell me
in what building the campus is?'"

In Regard To Rights
A goodly percentage of students often think and react
very strongly to problems of interest to them. These men
condemn or approve inwardly with enthusiasm. They
resent certain statements or allegations; they defend
boldly certain measures or attitudes—but all mentally,
to themselves. Why do they not let the world share in
their opinions? Why not aid in pushing whatever viewpoint they hold to further realization? Why do not
they put their thought in writing?

fundamentally. But one thing we should all agree
upon; and that is that there should be no denial of the
right of any side to express his opinion. And to uphold
this right we pledge ourselves wholeheartedly.
Once we have arrived at a conclusion, we will adhere
to it firmly and persistently. We hope to stir up some
thought; we hope to find some disagreement. And we
can concretely find this out by the written reactions of
students in letters to the editor.
Any correspondence, except that of a slanderous,
Libelous, or anonymous nature, will be respected and
printed-4n columns parallel to our written opinions.
Any request to withold publishing of the correspondent's
name will be honored and positively adhered to. A timehonored and permanent journalistic principle, into which
we firmly believe, will oblige us to insure absolute
secrecy of a writer's identity, if it is so requested.
